title: Romans Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:1, how should we receive him that is weak in the faith?
options: Receive him, but not to doubtful disputations
Receive him and argue with him
questions.correctAnswer: Receive him, but not to doubtful disputations
questions.explanation: Romans 14:1 instructs to receive the weak in faith but not engage in doubtful disputations.

questions.question: What does one man believe about eating according to Romans 14:2?
questions.correctAnswer: He may eat all things
questions.explanation: Romans 14:2 states that one man believes he may eat all things.

questions.question: Romans 14:3 says God has received whom?
options: Him that eateth and him that eateth not
questions.correctAnswer: Him that eateth and him that eateth not
questions.explanation: Romans 14:3 teaches that God has received both those who eat and those who do not eat.

questions.question: Who judges another man's servant according to Romans 14:4?
questions.correctAnswer: No one should judge him
questions.explanation: Romans 14:4 states that we should not judge another man's servant because he stands or falls to his own master.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:5, what should every man be regarding the esteem of days?
options: Fully persuaded in his own mind
questions.correctAnswer: Fully persuaded in his own mind
questions.explanation: Romans 14:5 says each man should be fully persuaded in his own mind about esteeming days.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:6, to whom does he who eats or regards the day do it?
questions.correctAnswer: To the Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 14:6 states that whether one regards the day or eats, it is unto the Lord and he gives God thanks.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14:7 says that none of us lives or dies to himself.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 14:7 clearly states that none of us lives to himself and no man dies to himself.

questions.question: Who is Lord of both the dead and living according to Romans 14:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 14:9 states that Christ died, rose, and revived to be Lord of both the dead and living.

questions.question: What will every knee do according to Romans 14:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Bow to the Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 14:11 says every knee shall bow to the Lord, and every tongue shall confess to God.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:12, to whom shall everyone give account of himself?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Romans 14:12 states that each person shall give account of himself to God.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14:13 says we should judge one another more often.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 14:13 instructs us not to judge one another anymore but rather to avoid causing others to stumble.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 14:14 says, 'There is nothing ________ of itself.'
questions.correctAnswer: unclean
questions.explanation: Romans 14:14 states that there is nothing unclean of itself.

questions.question: What should you not do if your brother is grieved with your meat, according to Romans 14:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy him with your meat
questions.explanation: Romans 14:15 warns not to destroy a brother with your meat for whom Christ died.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:17, what is the kingdom of God not about?
questions.correctAnswer: Meat and drink
questions.explanation: Romans 14:17 says the kingdom of God is not meat and drink but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14:23 states that whatever is not of faith is sin.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 14:23 clearly explains that whatever is not done in faith is sin.

medium.title: Romans Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Romans 14 teach us to treat a fellow believer who is weak in faith regarding disputations?
options: Receive him, but avoid doubtful disputations
Engage in debates to strengthen his faith
Judge him strictly for his weakness
questions.correctAnswer: Receive him, but avoid doubtful disputations
questions.explanation: Romans 14:1 instructs believers to receive those weak in faith but not to engage in doubtful disputations, promoting peace and understanding rather than conflict.

questions.question: What principle does Romans 14 teach about differing opinions on eating certain foods?
options: Do not despise or judge others for their dietary choices
Force others to eat all things
Avoid eating with those who differ
questions.correctAnswer: Do not despise or judge others for their dietary choices
questions.explanation: Romans 14:2-3 emphasizes that some may eat all things while others eat only herbs; neither should despise or judge the other because God has accepted them both.

questions.question: According to Romans 14, who is the ultimate judge of a servant's standing?
questions.correctAnswer: The servant's own master
questions.explanation: Romans 14:4 teaches that each person stands or falls to their own master, meaning God is the ultimate judge, not other humans.

questions.question: How should believers regard special days according to Romans 14?
options: Each should be fully persuaded in their own mind about their importance
All must observe the same holy days
Days do not matter and should be ignored
Only the Sabbath should be kept
questions.correctAnswer: Each should be fully persuaded in their own mind about their importance
questions.explanation: Romans 14:5 encourages believers to be fully convinced in their own minds about observing special days, respecting individual conviction.

questions.question: What is the motivation behind eating or not eating according to Romans 14?
options: To do it unto the Lord and give Him thanks
questions.correctAnswer: To do it unto the Lord and give Him thanks
questions.explanation: Romans 14:6 explains that whether one eats or abstains, it should be done unto the Lord, giving thanks to God.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14 teaches that each person lives and dies to themselves alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 14:7 states that no one lives or dies to themselves, emphasizing communal responsibility and accountability to God.

questions.question: What does Romans 14 say about the relationship between life, death, and the Lord?
options: Whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord
Life belongs to us, death belongs to others
We live for ourselves and die for the Lord
Death ends our relationship with the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 14:8 teaches that in life or death, believers belong to the Lord, highlighting God's sovereign ownership over life and death.

questions.question: Why should we not judge or despise our brother according to Romans 14?
options: Because we will all stand before the judgment seat of Christ
Because judging is a sin only for others
questions.correctAnswer: Because we will all stand before the judgment seat of Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 14:10 reminds believers that all will stand before Christ's judgment seat, so judging others is inappropriate and premature.

questions.question: What is the significance of every knee bowing and every tongue confessing as mentioned in Romans 14?
options: It shows the universal authority of the Lord
It is a symbolic gesture without meaning
It only applies to certain believers
It is a future event that will not affect us
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the universal authority of the Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 14:11 cites scripture that every knee shall bow and every tongue confess to God, affirming His ultimate authority over all.

questions.question: According to Romans 14, what should we avoid when interacting with brothers who have different convictions?
options: Putting a stumbling block or occasion to fall in their way
Forcing them to change their views
questions.correctAnswer: Putting a stumbling block or occasion to fall in their way
questions.explanation: Romans 14:13 urges believers not to judge but to avoid causing others to stumble through our actions.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I know, and am persuaded by the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing ____ of itself.'
questions.correctAnswer: unclean
questions.explanation: Romans 14:14 states that nothing is unclean in itself, emphasizing freedom in Christ regarding external matters.

questions.question: What does Romans 14 say about causing a brother to be grieved with your eating habits?
options: Do not destroy him with your meat, for whom Christ died
Ignore his feelings and eat freely
Challenge him to change his view
questions.correctAnswer: Do not destroy him with your meat, for whom Christ died
questions.explanation: Romans 14:15 warns that causing a brother to be grieved by our actions is uncharitable because Christ died for him.

questions.question: According to Romans 14, what constitutes the kingdom of God?
options: Righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 14:17 clarifies that the kingdom of God is not about food or drink but about righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 14, it is acceptable to eat anything even if it causes another believer to stumble or be offended.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 14:20-21 teaches that although all things are pure, it is wrong to eat if it causes a brother to stumble or be offended.

questions.question: How should a believer exercise faith according to Romans 14 when it comes to doubtful matters?
options: Keep it to themselves and not condemn themselves in what they allow
Force others to share the same faith
questions.correctAnswer: Keep it to themselves and not condemn themselves in what they allow
questions.explanation: Romans 14:22 encourages believers to have faith privately before God and be happy if they do not condemn themselves in what they allow.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:1, how should one receive the person who is weak in the faith?
options: Receive him, but not for doubtful disputations
Reject him because of his weakness
Judge him strictly according to the law
questions.correctAnswer: Receive him, but not for doubtful disputations
questions.explanation: Romans 14:1 instructs believers to receive those weak in faith without engaging in disputations that cause doubt, emphasizing acceptance over judgment.

questions.question: In Romans 14:2, what dietary practice is attributed to the one who is weak in faith?
options: Eating meat only on special days
questions.correctAnswer: Eating only herbs
questions.explanation: Romans 14:2 contrasts two believers: one who eats all things and another, weak in faith, who eats only herbs, showing differing convictions on dietary matters.

questions.question: What warning does Romans 14:3 give regarding judging others over dietary choices?
options: Do not despise or judge others for what they eat, for God has accepted them
Condemn those who do not eat as you do
Separate yourself from those with different diets
Enforce a uniform diet among believers
questions.correctAnswer: Do not despise or judge others for what they eat, for God has accepted them
questions.explanation: Romans 14:3 teaches that believers should not despise or judge others over eating habits because God has accepted them, highlighting God's sovereignty in acceptance.

questions.question: Romans 14:4 uses the example of judging another man's servant. What is the key teaching here?
options: Each person stands or falls before their own master, and God can make them stand
It is our duty to judge others' servants strictly
Masters are accountable to servants for their actions
Judgment should be public and communal
questions.correctAnswer: Each person stands or falls before their own master, and God can make them stand
questions.explanation: Romans 14:4 emphasizes that judgment belongs to the master (God), and He has power to uphold each servant, warning against human judgment.

questions.question: What does Romans 14:5 suggest about how believers view special days?
options: Some esteem one day above another, others esteem every day alike
All believers must observe the same holy days
Special days are unnecessary and should be ignored
Only the Sabbath is to be honored
questions.correctAnswer: Some esteem one day above another, others esteem every day alike
questions.explanation: Romans 14:5 acknowledges varying convictions about observing special days, advising each to be fully persuaded in their own mind.

questions.question: How does Romans 14:6 describe the attitude of those who eat or do not eat regarding the Lord?
options: Both eat and abstain to the Lord, giving thanks to God
Only those who eat properly honor the Lord
Those who do not eat dishonor the Lord
Eating habits have no spiritual significance
questions.correctAnswer: Both eat and abstain to the Lord, giving thanks to God
questions.explanation: Romans 14:6 explains that whether one eats or abstains, the act is done unto the Lord with thanksgiving, emphasizing sincere devotion over external acts.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14:7 declares that each person lives and dies solely for themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 14:7 clearly states that no one lives or dies to themselves, emphasizing communal responsibility and belonging to God.

questions.question: What is the ultimate lordship of Christ as presented in Romans 14:9?
options: Christ is Lord of both the dead and the living
Christ is Lord only of the living
Christ is Lord only of the dead
Christ's lordship is symbolic and limited
questions.correctAnswer: Christ is Lord of both the dead and the living
questions.explanation: Romans 14:9 affirms Christ's lordship over all humanity, living and dead, reflecting His resurrection and divine authority.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:10-11, why should believers refrain from judging one another?
options: Because all will stand before the judgment seat of Christ where every knee will bow and tongue confess
Because judgment is unnecessary in the church
Because only the apostles can judge
questions.correctAnswer: Because all will stand before the judgment seat of Christ where every knee will bow and tongue confess
questions.explanation: Romans 14:10-11 teaches that judgment belongs to Christ, to whom all will eventually submit, discouraging believers from judging each other prematurely.

questions.question: In Romans 14:12, what is each person required to do before God?
questions.correctAnswer: Give an account of themselves
questions.explanation: Romans 14:12 states that everyone will give an account of their own life and actions to God, underscoring personal responsibility.

questions.question: Romans 14:13 encourages believers to avoid what specific behavior towards one another?
options: Judging one another and causing others to stumble
questions.correctAnswer: Judging one another and causing others to stumble
questions.explanation: Romans 14:13 urges believers to stop judging but rather to avoid placing stumbling blocks in others' ways, promoting peace and edification.

questions.question: In Romans 14:14, what is said about things being unclean?
options: Nothing is unclean of itself, but to those who esteem anything unclean, it is unclean
All foods are unclean and should be avoided
Only certain meats are unclean according to the law
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing is unclean of itself, but to those who esteem anything unclean, it is unclean
questions.explanation: Romans 14:14 presents a principle based on the believer's conscience: no food is inherently unclean, but perceived uncleanness makes it so for the individual.

questions.question: What is the key reason in Romans 14:15 for avoiding actions that cause a brother to be grieved?
options: Because Christ died for that brother
Because it leads to social discord
Because it is a sign of weakness
questions.correctAnswer: Because Christ died for that brother
questions.explanation: Romans 14:15 appeals to love and respect for fellow believers, reminding that Christ died for them, so causing offense is destructive and uncharitable.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 14:17 defines the kingdom of God primarily as meat and drink.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 14:17 clarifies that the kingdom of God is not about meat and drink but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit, emphasizing spiritual over physical concerns.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:19-20, what should believers pursue, and what should they avoid?
options: Pursue peace and edification; avoid destroying the work of God by causing offense
Pursue strict dietary laws; avoid fellowship with the weak
Pursue public judgment; avoid private disagreements
Pursue personal freedom; avoid communal responsibilities
questions.correctAnswer: Pursue peace and edification; avoid destroying the work of God by causing offense
questions.explanation: Romans 14:19-20 emphasizes following what promotes peace and building others up, warning that causing offense can harm God's work among believers.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:1, how should the church receive those who are weak in faith?
options: Receive them, but not to doubtful disputations
Ignore their differences to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: Receive them, but not to doubtful disputations
questions.explanation: Romans 14:1 instructs believers to welcome those weak in faith without engaging in contentious debates. This reflects God's patience (2 Timothy 2:24-26), His acceptance of the weak (1 Corinthians 8:9-13), and the call to unity without judgment (John 13:34-35; Galatians 6:1).

questions.question: In Romans 14:2, what is the difference between the one who is strong in faith and the weak regarding food?
options: The strong eat all things; the weak eat herbs
The strong fast regularly; the weak eat all things
The strong only eat herbs; the weak eat meat
Both eat all things without concern
questions.correctAnswer: The strong eat all things; the weak eat herbs
questions.explanation: Romans 14:2 contrasts the liberty of the strong who eat all foods with the weak who restrict themselves, highlighting conscience and faith. This principle echoes Daniel 1:8-16 (dietary distinctions), 1 Corinthians 8:8-13 (food and conscience), and Levitical dietary laws (Leviticus 11).

questions.question: What reason does Romans 14:3 give for not despising or judging one another over food practices?
options: Because food is irrelevant to salvation
Because all foods are ceremonially clean
Because judgment belongs only to church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Because God has received them
questions.explanation: Romans 14:3 states that God has accepted both the eater and non-eater, emphasizing divine acceptance rather than human judgment. This aligns with Jesus' teaching on acceptance (Matthew 7:1-2), God's sovereignty (Psalm 125:3), and Paul's teaching on unity (Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: According to Romans 14:4, who ultimately determines whether a servant stands or falls?
questions.correctAnswer: His own master
questions.explanation: Romans 14:4 teaches that a servant stands or falls before his own master, who is God. This underscores God's authority over judgment (John 5:22; 2 Corinthians 5:10), sovereignty (Psalm 75:7), and the futility of human judgment (Matthew 7:1-5).

questions.question: What does Romans 14:5 say about how believers should regard special days?
options: Each should be fully persuaded in their own mind
Everyone must regard the same days as special
No days should be regarded as special
Only the Sabbath is to be honored
questions.correctAnswer: Each should be fully persuaded in their own mind
questions.explanation: Romans 14:5 affirms individual conscience in observing special days, respecting personal conviction. This aligns with Christ's teaching on liberty (Colossians 2:16-17), Paul's admonition on freedom (Galatians 5:1), and Old Testament ceremonial observance (Leviticus 23).

questions.question: How does Romans 14:6 describe the purpose of eating or not eating with regard to the Lord?
options: Both eating and not eating are done unto the Lord with thanksgiving
Eating is for personal satisfaction only
Not eating is a sign of spiritual superiority
Food practices have no spiritual significance
questions.correctAnswer: Both eating and not eating are done unto the Lord with thanksgiving
questions.explanation: Romans 14:6 teaches that whether one eats or abstains, the act is done for the Lord with thanksgiving. This reflects the principle of doing all for God's glory (1 Corinthians 10:31), gratitude (Psalm 107:8-9), and faith directed toward God (Hebrews 11:6).

questions.question: What theological truth about life and death does Romans 14:7-8 affirm?
options: Whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord
Life and death are controlled by human free will
Death ends all relationship with God
Only living for oneself has eternal significance
questions.correctAnswer: Whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 14:7-8 declares that life and death are under God's lordship, affirming our belonging to Him in all states. This corresponds to God's sovereignty over life (Job 1:21), resurrection hope (John 11:25), and eschatological assurance (1 Corinthians 15:54-57).

questions.question: What is the purpose of Christ’s death and resurrection according to Romans 14:9?
options: That He might be Lord of both the dead and living
To abolish the law of Moses
To guarantee wealth and health for believers
questions.correctAnswer: That He might be Lord of both the dead and living
questions.explanation: Romans 14:9 presents Christ’s death and resurrection as establishing His lordship over all humanity, dead and living. This aligns with Philippians 2:9-11, Acts 10:42, and Daniel 7:13-14, affirming His universal kingship and messianic fulfillment.

questions.question: Why does Romans 14:10 warn against judging or despising a brother?
options: Because all will stand before the judgment seat of Christ
Because some sins are worse than others
Because judgment is only for church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Because all will stand before the judgment seat of Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 14:10 cautions believers to refrain from judgment since everyone will give account before Christ. This is consistent with 2 Corinthians 5:10, Matthew 7:1-2, Ecclesiastes 12:14, and Hebrews 9:27, emphasizing divine judgment rather than human.

questions.question: What prophecy is cited in Romans 14:11 about every knee and tongue?
options: Every knee shall bow and every tongue confess to God
Only the righteous will bow to God
The Gentiles will bow but not Israel
Every knee will bow but tongues will remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: Every knee shall bow and every tongue confess to God
questions.explanation: Romans 14:11 quotes Isaiah 45:23, affirming universal submission to God. This is echoed in Philippians 2:10-11, Revelation 15:4, and Psalm 22:27, highlighting the eschatological acknowledgment of God's sovereignty.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:12, what will every person have to do before God?
questions.correctAnswer: Give account of himself
questions.explanation: Romans 14:12 states that each individual must give an account to God. This principle is found also in Matthew 12:36, 2 Corinthians 5:10, Hebrews 4:13, and Ezekiel 18:20, underscoring personal responsibility before God.

questions.question: What is the 'judgment' believers are encouraged to make according to Romans 14:13?
options: Judge that no one puts a stumbling block or occasion to fall before a brother
Judge the worthiness of church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Judge that no one puts a stumbling block or occasion to fall before a brother
questions.explanation: Romans 14:13 exhorts believers to avoid causing others to stumble rather than judging their conscience. This is consistent with 1 Corinthians 8:9-13, Matthew 18:6, Galatians 5:13, and 1 Thessalonians 5:14 emphasizing love and edification.

questions.question: What principle regarding clean and unclean things is taught in Romans 14:14?
options: Nothing is unclean of itself, but unclean to the one who regards it so
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing is unclean of itself, but unclean to the one who regards it so
questions.explanation: Romans 14:14 teaches that moral impurity depends on conscience, not the thing itself. This aligns with Mark 7:15, Acts 10:15, Leviticus 11 (ceremonial laws fulfilled in Christ), and 1 Timothy 4:4.

questions.question: Why does Romans 14:15 caution against causing a brother to be grieved with your food?
options: Because it is uncharitable and destroys the one for whom Christ died
Because it breaks the law of Moses
Because it is a sign of weakness in the faith
Because it is a personal preference with no spiritual consequence
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is uncharitable and destroys the one for whom Christ died
questions.explanation: Romans 14:15 warns that causing another to stumble through one's freedom is unloving and harms a redeemed brother. This teaching is supported by 1 Corinthians 8:11, Galatians 5:13, Ephesians 4:32, and John 13:34-35.

questions.question: What does Romans 14:17 say is the nature of the kingdom of God?
options: Righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 14:17 contrasts the kingdom of God with mere food and drink, emphasizing spiritual virtues empowered by the Holy Spirit. This is consistent with John 18:36, Galatians 5:22-23, Psalm 85:10, and Isaiah 9:7.
